title: How does 'rock & roll' differ from 'rock'? - Quora

response.answer_text: Good question that I’m not sure there’s a good answer to. The genre we all know and love now called “rock” started as Rock and Roll, the term was coined by Cleveland, Ohio DJ, Alan Freed as the name of part of his show, “The Rock and Roll Sessions”. Freed’s show featured a mix of country and rhythm and blues. I think I can remember hearing an interview (but I can’t recall who was being interviewed) and reading somewhere (again, can’t recall) that the “rock” was the uptempo mash-up of country (which had a swing to it) and blues (which had a thump to it) music; two forms of American Roots music. The swing in country is probably because much of it was written in 3/4 time (like a waltz). And the blues would have been 4/4 time which gave the all important “back-beat.” So, rock moved country to 4/4 time but “swung it a little” and upped the back-beat of the 4/4 blues music. It also used the 12-bar format of the blues. The roll part this is the part I seem to recall hearing and reading was the “gospel” music. The times were the segregated, Jim Crow south and the white folks took their religion with great solemnity, but the people of color, they reveled in their religion and enjoyed the worship. So much so that some churches had folks falling to their knees and rolling around while the choir sang and the preacher preached. All filled with the spirit of the Lord. The song considered to be the first rock and roll song, Rocket 88 by Ike Turner brought together these influences, which inspired Little Richard, Elvis Presley and others. Soon, more geographical variances were being added but it stayed rock and roll…until the Beatles. The Beatles started copying these early soon to be rock and roll legends and mixed it with some of the popular radio play (pop music) when they started writing their own songs. Then when the Beatles became a little more experimental, musically, the genre was shortened to “rock” because now classical music, Indian music and previous recordings were being mixed into the new recordings. It wasn’t just the Beatles who were doing these things but they were popular, so if a lot of people knew about it it was because the Beatles did it. But shortening “rock and roll” to “rock” allowed hyphenated sub-genres to occur like Progressive Rock, Art Rock, Glam Rock, Punk Rock, Southern Rock, Hard Rock, Soft Rock, Heavy Metal, et al. In my opinion, “rock” is a catch-all name for what doesn't fit neatly somewhere else like Rhythm & Blues, Gospel, Country and Western, Classical, Electronic Dance Music, etc. Where Rock & Roll identified a new blend of old music styles, Rock encompasses where that formula has taken it since 1951. If anyone has heard the interview or read the book or article, please post it for those who are interested because it was a fascinating time. Thank you for reading this answer.

To understand the difference it may be useful to examine what happened around the time rock ’n’ roll was changing into rock, in 1964–65. There were a handful of key songs, released within a few months of each other. You Really Got Me by The Kinks had the heavily distorted power chords that later became a staple of early rock. They were doing British Pop Rock, but still the song gets mentioned a lot as the genesis of the transition.   Then came For Your Love by The Yardbirds. Another banger that came out a month before . . . Ticket to Ride, The Beatles third consecutive #1 song in the US. The rhythm is decidedly not rock ’n’ roll. John Lennon said he wanted the band to do something “heavy.” The lyrics are still rock ’n’ roll (girl trouble) but the sound was huge and seemed like something completely different. It wasn’t, really, because Phil Spector had been producing this “huge” sound within the rock ’n’ roll genre previously. Lennon had the Fabs reproduce Spector with layers of loud electric guitars, and later claimed they’d played the “first heavy metal song.” Then came Bob Dylan’s Like a Rolling Stone. The Beatles had been listening to Dylan, and Dylan had heard them, too. So he picked up a Fender Stratocaster like his hero Buddy Holly and turned his acerbic folk music into rock music. These songs were big hits by big names in popular music. People noticed. Other musicians and record producers, especially. Then this guy named Jimi Hendrix heard both of them and started to believe that the explosion of ideas he’d always had about electric guitar and music might actually be commercially viable. So did Chas Chandler, bassist for The Animals, who bankrolled Jimi’s first album, Are You Experienced? The music on that album was a mashup of many genres, all played on Buddy Holly’s rock ’n’ roll Stratocaster that didn’t sound anything like rock ’n’ roll. Okay so what was happening? Rock ’n’ roll before was basically considered one genre. Surf Rock, Rockabilly, whatever, if there were electric guitars and it wasn’t country music or jazz, people considered it rock ’n’ roll. The concept of “garage rock” didn’t exist yet, so raucous bands like The Kingsmen or The Wailers were just noisy rock ’n’ rollers. So were The Beatles, initially, with a dab of Everly Brothers (and again, Holly) mixed in. Then between ’65 and ‘67, rock ’n’ roll began fragmenting into a bunch of sub-genres. Brian Wilson’s rock ’n’ roll Beach Boys put out Pet Sounds, a landmark early “rock” album. Hendrix and bands like Jefferson Airplane were putting out “psychedelic rock.” The Beatles put out Sergeant Pepper’s and released no singles from the album. Rock ’n’ roll had been all about selling 45-rpm singles. Hendrix’ first LP spawned no Top-10 singles in the US, yet it was the top-selling album of 1968. Rock ’n’ roll didn’t completely die, though. It just became one of the many sub-genres of “rock” as the music form expanded to incorporate other influences. Blues Rock was really big. Country Rock became a thing. Keyboardists started playing through guitar amps and all the weird scales they knew became Metal and Prog Rock. The list goes on, but basically anything with an electric guitar featured gets the “Rock” moniker.  These rock-n-rollers played right before Hendrix at Woodstock in 1969. So. The rock ’n’ roll genre has features from swing and jump blues, doo wop and country music. It’s fairly recognizable for its first-person lyrics about love and cars and some very familiar chord progressions. If it sounds like Buddy Holly or Chuck Berry, it’s rock ’n’ roll. Holly’s rock-band combo The Crickets was the ne plus ultra of the genre. And people can almost always dance to it. Then there’s all the electric-guitar stuff that happened after mid-’65, Ticket to Ride, Like a Rolling Stone and Hendrix’ Purple Haze. That’s not rock ’n’ roll any more. It’s a big, convoluted mass of genres intermixing under an umbrella term called “Rock.” And people usually listen to it.
